## Starting off with GDP Growth Rate 


* Data source: World Bank World Development Indicators (WDI) [@worldbank2026].

::: {#c527c0d9 .cell execution_count=1}
``` {.python .cell-code}
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

data = pd.read_csv('wdi.csv')

print("\n=== GDP GROWTH RATE ===")
print(data['gdp_growth_rate'].describe())
print(f"Observations: {len(data)}")
print(f"Proportion of Increasing GDP: {(data['gdp_growth_rate'].dropna() > 0).sum()/len(data)}")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

=== GDP GROWTH RATE ===
count    202.000000
mean       4.368901
std        6.626811
min      -28.758591
25%        2.438593
50%        4.204431
75%        6.200000
max       63.439864
Name: gdp_growth_rate, dtype: float64
Observations: 217
Proportion of Increasing GDP: 0.8433179723502304
```
:::
:::


::: {#cell-fig-gdp-dist .cell execution_count=2}

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display}
![Plot of GDP Growth Rate Distribution](slides_files/figure-revealjs/fig-gdp-dist-output-1.png){#fig-gdp-dist width=808 height=449}
:::
:::


## Measles Immunization vs GDP Per Capita

::: {#8261a332 .cell execution_count=3}
``` {.python .cell-code}
data_plot2 = data.dropna(subset=['measles_immunisation_rate','gdp_per_capita'])
correlation = data_plot2['gdp_per_capita'].corr(data_plot2['measles_immunisation_rate'])
print(f"\nCorrelation: {correlation:.3f}")
print(f"Observations: {len(data_plot2)}")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

Correlation: 0.314
Observations: 186
```
:::
:::


::: {#cell-fig-gdp-measles-scatter .cell execution_count=4}

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display}
![Relationship between GDP per Capita and Measles Immunisation Rate](slides_files/figure-revealjs/fig-gdp-measles-scatter-output-1.png){#fig-gdp-measles-scatter width=948 height=564}
:::
:::


## Life Expectancy Vs GDP Per Capita

::: {#340d2616 .cell execution_count=5}
``` {.python .cell-code}
data_plot3 = data.dropna(subset=['life_expectancy','gdp_per_capita'])
correlation = data_plot3['gdp_per_capita'].corr(data_plot3['life_expectancy'])
print(f"\nCorrelation: {correlation:.3f}")
print(f"Observations: {len(data_plot3)}")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

Correlation: 0.639
Observations: 197
```
:::
:::


::: {#cell-fig-gdp-life-expectancy .cell execution_count=6}

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display}
![Relationship between GDP per Capita and Life Expectancy](slides_files/figure-revealjs/fig-gdp-life-expectancy-output-1.png){#fig-gdp-life-expectancy width=949 height=564}
:::
:::


## Summary
| Variable                                  | Observations | Mean  | Std. Dev. | Min    | Median | Max   | Correlation |
| ----------------------------------------- | ------------ | ----- | --------- | ------ | ------ | ----- | ----------- |
| GDP Growth Rate (%)                       | 202          | 4.37  | 6.63      | -28.76 | 4.20   | 63.44 | —           |
| Proportion of Countries with Positive GDP | 217          | 0.843 | —         | —      | —      | —     | —           |
| GDP per Capita vs Immunisation Rate       | 186          | —     | —         | —      | —      | —     | 0.314       |
| GDP per Capita vs Life Expectancy         | 197          | —     | —         | —      | —      | —     | 0.639       |
: Table of Key Statistics {#tbl-stats}


## Conclusion of Analysis

As shown in @tbl-stats, the average GDP growth rate across countries is 4.37%, with substantial dispersion given the standard deviation of 6.63. The minimum value of -28.76% highlights extreme economic contractions in some countries.

The distribution of GDP growth rates is illustrated in @fig-gdp-dist, which shows a right-skewed distribution with several high-growth outliers. The histogram confirms that most countries cluster between 0% and 10% growth.

The relationship between GDP per capita and measles immunisation is presented in @fig-gdp-measles-scatter. As reported in @tbl-stats, the correlation is 0.314, indicating a moderate positive association.

In contrast, @fig-gdp-life-expectancy shows a stronger relationship between GDP per capita and life expectancy. The correlation of 0.639 (see @tbl-stats) suggests a substantially stronger link between income levels and longevity outcomes.
